better painter maybe hey guys welcome back to another episode of black magic
craft this episode I want to talk about wet palettes something that people swear
by there is a lot of hype around from those who use one but do you need one
what is it can you make your own these are a few things I want to talk about
today what is a wet palette essentially it's a place where you can pour out and
mix paint that will keep your paint hydrated unlike a regular plastic
palette or just using a piece of cardboard or whatever a wet palette has
a sponge or a damp paper towel that is topped with another piece of paper that
keeps your paint hydrated and why is this important well it's important for a
few reasons it stops your paint from drying out if
you're using craft paint in large quantities to paint terrain this isn't
really a concern because you have so much paint poured out at a time that
it's unlikely to dry out and even if it does it's cheap paint so it doesn't
really matter however when you start using more expensive paints designed for
miniatures you're gonna be pouring out a lot less paint on your palette or lish
you should be because why waste expensive paint and when you only have a
few drops of paint on your palette it can quickly dry out causing a lot of
wastage also if you are mixing colors especially in miniature painting and
you're going to be painting over the course of several days or periods it
could be very challenging to try and mix up the exact same color that you mix
yesterday or the week before the nice thing about the wet palette is it allows
you to save these mixed colors and come back to them days later and they're
still wet and ready to use the other great thing about a wet palette and the
reason they actually improve your painting especially for amateurs is that
it slightly thins your paint when you are painting miniatures this is really
important that you get good at thinning your paint so that you apply thin layers
not thick layers so that detail isn't obscured and it flows nicely there
the number one thing painters will tell you when mini painting for beginners is
to thin your paint and people tend to not listen to this advice if you use a
wet palette it naturally does that a little bit for you because of the added
hydration on the palette so how do they work
essentially it is just a plastic container that has a somewhat airtight
lid in which you can place a damp sponge cloth or paper towel and top with a
certain type of paper something like parchment paper and the way it works is
that this container will seal when you're not using it so it'll keep your
paint hydrated the sponge and the paper will wick up some of that water but not
too much and it will keep your paint surface moist that's it it's very simple
and you might be wondering why would I go and buy one of these when I can make
one myself and that is a perfect way to be thinking you can absolutely make your
own wet palette all you need is a Tupperware container the shallower the
better because when you're painting you don't want to have to be reaching in and
dipping into a deep container so get yourself a shallow Tupperware container
take a folded up paper towel or sponge or chamois type cloth get it nice and
wet not too wet wring out some of the excess but you want it fairly damp put
it in the bottom of the container and top that with some parchment paper you
don't want to use wax paper because the wax won't let the water flow through you
want to use parchment paper or baking paper that's not of the
lacks variety then you can mix on this surface your paint will hydrate you can
close your lid and come back to it later and boom you have yourself a homemade
wet palette there is a commercially available wet palette that you can buy
from your local craft or hobby store or pickup on Amazon and it is just a
slightly better version of the homemade variety now when I first tried a wet
palette I was reluctant I didn't really believe the hype so I figured what's the
harm in making a homemade one that cost me nothing to try it out and I did that
and after using it for like a week mini painting I was sold I was 100% on the
wet palette training I was like this is awesome
totally converted decided I would be using one for all of my miniature
painting moving forward the problem I had with my homemade one is that the
shallowest Tupperware container I could find was still like an inch and a half
or two inches tall or something like that and I found it annoying to reach in
to get my paint so when I saw the one that you could buy and I saw that was
really really shallow and it wasn't that expensive I decided to pick one up the
one that you can buy consists of three components there's the container the
sponge and the special paper that it comes with what's important to know is
if you're gonna buy one of these the tray the shallow tray is worth every

paper towel however you could probably pick up something similar at a dollar
store the special paper that it comes with I thought wow this comes with

bought mine I actually bought a pack of a hundred of these sheets of this paper
because I wanted to stock up that was a mistake
turns out the paper that comes with the commercially available wet palette is a

first of all you can't just open the paper and put it in you have to prepare

handle that so I did that and I tried it what I realized however is that this
paper was really designed to be used on a wet palette for artists still using
larger quantities of paint this paper was still porous and kind of dry not
nice and slick as compared to the parchment paper that I was used to using

that I decided you know what I like the way the parchment paper worked so I took

palette that I had bought and all of a sudden I had the perfect wet palette I

it's shallow the sponge works great parchment paper works awesome so that is
